properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system from the eastern American seaboard will move across Eastern Quebec tonight and tomorrow. This system will bring from 30 to 50 millimetres of rain over several areas of Central and Eastern Quebec. The rain will taper off Saturday in the central areas of the province, the North Shore and the Gaspé Peninsula. However, rain will reach the Lower North Shore on Saturday evening, where similar amounts will be possible through Sunday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-17T11:18:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-16T19:19:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1164441763.2020
Area: Manic-5 area, Manic-3 area, Labrieville area, Forestville area, Les Escoumins area, Sainte-Rose-du-Nord area, Rivière-Éternité - Petit-Saguenay area, Tadoussac - Baie-Sainte-Catherine area, La Malbaie area, Baie-Saint-Paul area, Matane, Amqui area, Matapédia area, Baie-Comeau, Baie-Trinité area, Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier area, Minganie, Anticosti

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The first significant snowfall of the season is possible this weekend. Snow is expected to begin north of Lake Superior late Saturday afternoon and taper off on Sunday morning. Current indications suggest snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible. Heavy snow could affect road conditions and visibilities. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. Snowfall Warnings may be required as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-17T12:15:38-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High westerly winds gusting up to 100 kilometres per hour are expected over these areas overnight tonight. Winds will diminish gradually beginning early Sunday morning. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-18T00:31:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-17T08:32:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2716083489.2020
Area: Grande-Vallée area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area, Minganie, Anticosti
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Waterspout Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions will be favourable for the development of waterspouts this evening. The risk will remain through the overnight hours and into Saturday morning. ### Wind speeds inside the spray ring of a waterspout are 45 knots or higher. Vulnerable vessels are at risk of damage or capsizing. Keep in mind that waterspouts cannot be seen at night and may strike suddenly. Waterspouts are generally isolated in nature although they can also occur in families of two or more. Waterspouts sometimes appear as funnel clouds with swirling water visible near the surface. Waterspouts are generated by weak rotation under rapidly growing clouds or weak thunderstorms. Under favourable conditions, this weak rotation could intensify and become a tornado. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
Expires: 2020-10-17T18:52:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-17T02:53:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0835209668.2020
Area: Eastern Lake Erie, Western Lake Erie
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The first significant snowfall of the season is possible this weekend. Snow is expected to begin in Northwestern Ontario on Saturday morning and into the afternoon. The snow will taper off by early Sunday morning. Current indications suggest snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible. However, with warmer temperatures and a mix of rain and snow expected near Lake Superior, snowfall amounts could be much less along the lakeshore. Heavy snow could affect road conditions and visibilities. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. Snowfall Warnings may be required as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-17T12:16:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-16T20:17:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3693297942.2020

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A band of heavy snow will continue to give significant accumulations to western Alberta this evening. The highest amounts are expected to fall along the foothills and Rocky Mountains. Total accumulations are expected to approach 10 cm but local amounts of 15 cm or more may fall over the higher elevations. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. High westerly winds gusting up to 90 kilometres per hour are expected over the northern shore of the Gaspé peninsula on Saturday night. Winds will diminish gradually beginning early Sunday morning. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long-lived snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls are expected continue along the southern shore of Great Slave Lake near and east of the community of Fort Resolution into Saturday. Snowfall amounts will range significantly depending on where the snow squall sets up, but local total accumulations by afternoon Saturday could exceed 25 cm. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-17T19:24:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-17T03:25:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2813000589.2020
Area: Ft. Resolution Region including Hwy. 6

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Periods of heavy rain is expected today and tonight. Time frame: today and this evening. Locations: northwestern New Brunswick. Total rainfall amounts: 50 millimetres or more. Remarks: Rain at times heavy is expected to redevelop this morning and end before midnight tonight. Additionally, there is likely to be some wet snow mixing with the rain over higher terrain this evening before it ends. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Be prepared for possible winter conditions at higher elevations. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-17T23:23:07-00:00

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly 120 km/h Time span: early this evening until late overnight. Location: Wreckhouse area. Remarks: Winds are expected to gust near 80 km/h late this morning before gradually increasing to 120 km/h this evening. Winds will ease upon shifting to westerly before Sunday morning. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm continues. A Pacific low pressure system is moving across the central interior. Snow from the system has tapered off over parts of the central interior but it will continue near Tumbler Ridge in the southern BC Peace and Yellowhead Pass. Further accumulations of 5 cm can be expected. The snow will end this afternoon as the low moves into Alberta. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
